div.p: Integrating mobile edge computing (MEC) into the Internet of Things (IoT) enables the IoT devices of limited computation capabilities and energy to offload their computationintensive and delay-sensitive tasks to the network edge, thereby providing high quality of service to the devices. In this paper, we apply non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) technique to enable massive connectivity and investigate how it can be exploited to achieve energy-efficient MEC in IoT networks. In order to maximize the energy efficiency for offloading, while simultaneously satisfying the maximum tolerable delay constraints of IoT devices, a joint radio and computation resource allocation problem is formulated, which takes both intra-and inter-cell interference into consideration. To tackle this intractable mixed integer non-convex problem, we first decouple it into separated radio and computation resource allocation problems. Then, the radio resource allocation problem is further decomposed into a subchannel allocation problem and a power allocation problem, which can be solved by matching and sequential convex programming algorithms, respectively. Based on the obtained radio resource allocation solution, the computation resource allocation problem can be solved by utilizing the Knapsack method. Numerical results validate our analysis and show that our proposed scheme can significantly improve the energy efficiency of NOMAenabled MEC in IoT networks compared to the existing baselines.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Massive Internet of Things (mIoT) is an essential component of future wireless networks, which has been envisioned to interconnect massive number of devices from various environments and support many novel applications. Traditionally, the IoT applications are operated in a centralized manner. That is, the IoT devices send their data to a remote cloud for further computing and processing. However, according to Cisco's report [1], the global machine-type data traffic will reach 25 exabytes per month by 2022, which is a sevenfold increase over 2017. This huge amount of data traffic will introduce significant load to the already-congested backbone networks, making it increasingly impractical to utilize the remote cloud alone to process the ever growing distributed data. Against this backdrop, mobile edge computing (MEC) [2]- [5], which deploys computing functionalities and storage resources at the network edge, e.g., small-cell base stations (SBSs), has been recognized as a promising solution to relieve the backhaul load, reduce the latency, and provide fast-response data processing services for users.

Another key feature of mIoT is high connection density. It has been predicted that the number of the IoT devices will reach 20.8 billion by 2020 [6], which poses great challenges for the traditional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) scheme to fulfill the high connection density requirement. To address this issue, non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) technique [7]- [12] has been proposed as an alternative for traditional OMA, due to the fact that it can achieve massive connections, improve the spectrum efficiency, and reduce the delay. The key idea of NOMA is to allow multiple users to transmit on the same resource block simultaneously, and successive interference cancelation (SIC) is used as an efficient multi-user detection technique at the receiver to reduce the co-channel interference and decode the target signal.

Motivated by the benefits of MEC and NOMA, increasing research attention has been paid to integrate MEC and NOMA into wireless networks [13]- [16]. Specifically, the authors in [13] proposed heuristic algorithms for MEC-aware NOMA single cell, in which the user clustering, computation resource and transmission powers allocation were jointly optimized to minimize the energy consumption. In [14], the authors proposed a joint optimization scheme of SIC ordering and computation resource in a MEC-aware NOMA NB-IoT network, in order to minimize the total execution delay for each bit. The authors in [15] considered two kinds of users scenarios, including the single user and the multiple users, in which the offloading workloads and transmission time were both optimized to minimize the delay, while satisfying the computation requirement of each user. In [16], the authors proposed a scheduling-based algorithm for the device-todevice (D2D)-assisted and NOMA-based MEC system, in which D2D was applied to enhance the user collaboration and relieve the computing burden on edge server, and the computation resource, power, and channel allocations were jointly optimized to minimize the system cost.

The aforementioned works [13]- [16] focused on the singlecell networks. Recently, the more general and compelling problem of NOMA-assisted MEC in multi-cell networks has been attracting increasing research attention [17], [18]. Specifically, the authors in [17] investigated the joint power and computation resource allocation allocation scheme for the NOMA-

• We propose an energy-efficient NOMA-based MEC design for multi-cell network with mIoT devices. In this design, we formulate a joint communication and computation resource allocation problem in order to maximize the energy efficiency for offloading, while ensuring successful task execution at each device within their tolerable computation delay. • We decouple the non-convex energy efficiency maximization problem into two separated subproblems, i.e., the communication resource allocation and the computation resource allocation problems, and show how the energy efficiency can be maximized by solving these problems iteratively.

Beyond the above contributions, the results presented in our work provide the insights into the design of novel schemes for multi-cell networks that simultaneously enable massive access and energy-efficient MEC. Specifically, we examine the impacts of system parameters, such as the number of users accessing the same subchannel, the number of computing RBs, the workload of users, and the tolerable delay for offloading on the energy efficiency of our proposed design, showing how the maximum energy efficiency can be achieved by judiciously matching the communication resources with the computation resources.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the system model is presented and the problem is formulated. Section III develops the joint radio and computation resource allocation scheme. Section IV presents the simulation results. Finally, section V draws the conclusion.

div.head: II. SYSTEM MODEL AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), we consider mobile edge computing in a multi-cell network with N single-antenna SBSs and U single-antenna IoT devices (e.g., sensors and meters), indexed by
div.formula: N = {1, 2, • • • , N } and U = {1, 2, • • • , U }, respectively. The total system bandwidth, B, is equally divided into M orthogonal subchannels, indexed by M = {1, 2, • • • , M }.
div.p: We consider the use of the nearest BS association policy [19]. As such, each IoT device associates with the nearest SBS that can provide the maximum average channel gain. We denote the set of devices served by SBS n as U n . Considering the limited computing capabilities and energy storage of IoT devices, the sensed data needs to be offloaded to the MEC server for processing to get some useful information, e.g., the further instruction for IoT devices and the feedback for subscribed users. Therefore, each device u ∈ U offloads its computation tasks to its associated SBS n ∈ N via subchannel m ∈ M. We assume that M < N . As such, the devices associated with different SBSs may access to the same subchannel and interfere with each other. We denote the set of devices served by SBS n on subchannel m as U m n .

div.head: IV. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, simulation results are provided to verify the energy efficiency performance of the NOMA-MEC-enabled multi-cell networks. We deploy 3 SBSs and 1000 users in the network. The system bandwidth is 10 MHz, which is available to all the SBSs. In addition, we assume that each subchannel is able to be accessed by at most 2 devices, namely Z m = 2. The uplink channels are all independent and identically distributed Rayleigh fading channels. Unless otherwise specified, other parameters used throughout the simulations are summarized in Table I.

div.head: A. Performance Analysis of Communication Resource
div.p: We first examine the performance of our proposed algorithms and analyze the effect of communication resource on the offloading energy efficiency in Fig. 3 -Fig. 8. Fig. 3 verifies the convergence of our proposed matching algorithm for different number of devices. It is observed that, our proposed matching algorithm can converges to a stationary point within 5-10 iterations for different number of devices. It is also observed that the number of iterations required for convergence increases as the number of devices increase, due to the increased searching space in matching process. In addition, it is seen that, the performance of the proposed 2 We note that this operation may lead to the case where the devices with high energy efficiency are not assigned with computing RBs, when allocating computing RBs to these devices would violate the computation resource constraint. matching algorithm is close to the exhaustive searching (ES) method, indicating the effectiveness of our proposed matching algorithm. Fig. 4 evaluates the average energy efficiency of our proposed NOMA scheme for different number of devices. For comparison purpose, we also provide the energy efficiencies achieved by the OMA scheme and the NOMA with equal power allocation (NOMA-EPAA) scheme. Note that, in the NOMA-EPAA scheme, the transmission power of each device is equally distributed among all the subchannels. It is seen that, for all three schemes, the energy efficiency increases as the number of SBSs increases. It is also seen that, when the number of SBSs is small, the advantage of our proposed NOMA-enabled scheme over the OMA scheme is not significant. This is because, the subchannels in the system are able to support the uplink transmissions of all the devices when the number of devices is small. In Fig. 5, we plot the average energy efficiency versus the maximum number of devices sharing the same subchannel, i.e., Z m . With the fixed number of devices, the average energy efficiency grows with Z m , due to the fact that more devices can be accommodated by the system with a larger Z m and subsequently the system throughput increases. In addition, the growth rate becomes smaller when Z m becomes relatively large, since more co-channel interference are introduced to the same subchannel as Z m increases.

In Fig. 6, we plot the connection density ratio versus the maximum number of devices sharing the same subchannel. Specifically, the connection density ratio is defined as the number of scheduled devices divided by the number of all the devices. The scheduled devices are those scheduled to offload their tasks in the same transmission interval. Similar as in Fig. 5, it is seen that the connection density ratio increases with Z m . In addition, for a given Z m , the connection density ratio decreases as the number of devices increases. This is because the number of scheduled devices are only determined by the number of subchannels and the value of Z m . Thus, the more devices leads to the larger denominator and the smaller connection density ratio.

The relationship between the average energy efficiency and the maximum transmission power of each device is illustrated in Fig. 7. We can see that, for a fixed number of devices, the energy efficiency increases with the maximum transmission power, which demonstrates that the sum rate grows faster than the system power consumption. In addition, we see that the performance gap between our proposed NOMA scheme and the OMA scheme increases as the number of devices increases, showing how the application of NOMA can significantly enhance the system performance by allowing multiple devices to share the same channel resources simultaneously. Next, we show how the proposed scheme can ensure the device fairness in Fig. 8. In this figure, Jain's fairness index [?] is adopted as the metric for the device fairness, given by
div.formula: F airness Index = ( ∑ M m=1 η m ) 2 M × ∑ M m=1 (η m ) 2 . (37
div.p: The value of Jain's fairness index can vary from 0 and 1, and fairness of resource allocation scheme increases as the value increases. It is observed that, for all three schemes, Jain's fairness index decreases with the number of devices in each SBS. The reason is that, with more devices, the competition for limited radio and computation resources becomes more fierce. Consequently, more devices with poor channel conditions are not allowed to access the subchannel and more offloaded tasks of devices with smaller contribution to energy efficiency are not allowed to be computed in the SBS. Moreover, it is seen that, with fixed number of devices, our proposed NOMA scheme achieves the best fairness performance and OMA scheme is the worst, due to the fact that NOMA technique enhances the utilization of multi-device diversity.

The proposed NOMA scheme outperforms the NOMA-EPAA scheme in fairness due to the fairer and more reasonable power allocation method. Furthermore, it is worth noting that by allowing more devices sharing the same subchannel, both three schemes are able to achieve higher fairness indices, which is also attributed to the utilization of multi-device diversity.

div.head: B. Performance Analysis of Computation Resource
div.p: In the following, we examine the impact of computation resource on the offloading performance in Fig. 9 -Fig. 11. Fig. 9 evaluates the average energy efficiency of different schemes versus the number of computing RBs in each SBS. It can be seen that, for a fixed number of devices, the average energy efficiency first increases and then approaches a fixed value as the number of computing RBs increases. This is because, when the number of computing RBs is small, increasing the number of computing RBs enables each SBS to process more offloaded tasks. However, when the number of computing RBs becomes relatively large, each SBS is capable of processing all the offloaded tasks. As such, increasing the number computing RBs at each SBS does not improve the average energy efficiency. This is consistent with our analysis in Section III-B, which again indicates that the number of computing RBs assigned to each SBS should be in accordance with the number of its serving devices. Moreover, it is seen that, as expected, our proposed NOMA scheme outperforms the OMA scheme, and the performance gap increases as the number of devices increases.

In Fig. 10, the impact of the size of offloaded tasks at each device on energy efficiency performance is investigated. It is observed that the average energy efficiency decreases as the size of offloaded task increases. the same constraint of its tolerable delay when the size of tasks increases. Consequently, less tasks can be handled in a slot and thus leads to the reduction of average energy efficiency. It is also observed that the reduction of average energy efficiency becomes less significant as the number of computing RBs at each SBS increases from 800 to 1600.

Finally, Fig. 11 examines the relationship between the average energy efficiency and the maximum tolerable delay of each device for a fixed number of devices and different number of computing RBs in each SBS n, i.e., U = 1000 and CB n = {400, 800}. Again, it is seen that our proposed NOMA scheme always achieves a better performance than the OMA scheme, and the performance gap is more profound when the maximum tolerable delay is small. It is also seen that the average energy efficiency of both NOMA and OMA schemes increases as the maximum tolerable delay increases. This is because, when the delay constraint becomes loose, the number of computing RBs required for each device meeting the delay constraint decreases, which in turn increases the throughput of the system. Similarly, the energy efficiency decreases sharply as the delay restriction becomes strict. Besides, it is worth noting that the average energy efficiency tends to be constant when the tolerable delay is relatively large. The reason is that delay is a key limiting factor in energy efficiency performance when it is small. When it is large enough, its influence on energy efficiency is no longer working.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we focused on the mIoT scenario with requirements of massive connectivity and low delay, and proposed a joint radio and computation resource allocation scheme for NOMA-enabled MEC in multi-cell networks, in which multiple devices applied NOMA technique to offload their computation tasks to edge SBSs simultaneously. In the proposed scheme, we jointly optimized the subchannel allocation, power allocation, as well as the computing RB allocation to maximize the energy efficiency for offloading, while satisfying the offloading delay requirement of each device. Simulation results verified the effectiveness and superiority of our proposed algorithms on energy efficiency compared to the existing baselines.
